meta.title: Build Your Child's Calm-Down Toolkit
meta.description: Answer a few questions about how your child processes big emotions, and get a personalized set of calming strategies matched to their temperament.
meta.intro: Every child calms down differently. Some need to move, some need to squeeze something, some need to talk it out. This quiz builds a toolkit that actually fits YOUR kid — not a generic checklist.
meta.subject: your child
meta.shareCta: Build a personalized calm-down toolkit for your child

questions.text: When your child is wound up or upset, their body usually...

options.text: Gets very physical — running, jumping, climbing, throwing things
Gets tense — clenching fists, stiffening up, stomping
Goes still — freezing, shutting down, curling up
It varies a lot depending on the situation

questions.text: What tends to soothe your child when they're overwhelmed?

options.text: Being wrapped in a blanket, a tight hug, or deep pressure
Quiet music, white noise, or rhythmic sounds
They don't really have a go-to sensory comfort yet
Fidgeting with something — squishing, tearing, pulling

questions.text: After your child calms down from a meltdown, they typically...
questions.subtext: Think about what happens once the storm passes.

options.text: Want to talk about what happened and why they were upset
Can talk about it if you bring it up gently
Don't want to talk about it at all — they just want to move on
Can't really explain what happened even if they try

questions.text: When your child has been sitting still for too long (car ride, waiting room, class), they...

options.text: Start bouncing, fidgeting, or literally climbing the walls
Get increasingly cranky and irritable
Zone out or get quiet
Can manage for a while but get restless eventually

questions.text: How does your child respond to unexpected loud noises or chaotic environments?

options.text: Covers ears, hides, or cries — very sensitive to sensory overload
Gets a bit unsettled but can usually cope
Barely notices — they're pretty unfazed by noise and chaos
Gets MORE energized — loud environments seem to amp them up

questions.text: If you gave your child a choice between calming strategies, they'd most likely pick...

options.text: "Let's talk about what happened" or looking at a feelings chart together
"Count to 10" or taking deep breaths
They wouldn't pick any — they're not ready for deliberate strategies yet
Something physical — squeeze a ball, jump, hit a pillow

questions.text: After running around or doing something physical, your child usually...

options.text: Is visibly calmer and more regulated — the energy release really helps
Is somewhat calmer but can also get more wound up
Doesn't seem to change much — physical activity isn't a reset button for them
Gets more dysregulated — high energy leads to higher energy

questions.text: Does your child seek out any of these when they're stressed?
questions.subtext: Think about their natural comfort-seeking behavior.

options.text: A favorite soft toy, blanket, or clothing item with a specific texture
Water play, playdough, sand, or other hands-on materials
Not really — they don't gravitate toward tactile comfort objects
Food or sucking/chewing (thumb, chewy toy, snacks)

questions.text: When you try to help your child name their feelings during a tough moment...

options.text: It actually helps — they calm down faster when they can label what's happening
Sometimes helps, sometimes they're too far gone to listen
Makes things worse — they yell "STOP TALKING!" or escalate
They don't understand the emotion words yet — it goes over their head

high.headline: Movement is their reset button
high.detail: Your child processes big emotions through their body. When feelings build up, they NEED to move — it's not misbehavior, it's their nervous system doing its job. Physical release is the fastest path back to calm for this kid.
high.strength:
Build these into the toolkit:
• **Jump station** — mini trampoline, jumping jacks, or "jump 10 times as hard as you can"
• **Push & pull** — push against a wall, carry heavy things, tug-of-war with a towel
• **Run it out** — a designated "run to the fence and back" route
• **Animal walks** — bear crawls, crab walks, frog jumps (works indoors too)
• **Squeeze station** — stress balls, playdough, balled-up socks to squeeze and throw

medium.headline: Movement helps, but isn't everything
medium.detail: Physical activity can help your child regulate, but it's not their primary channel. Some movement is good, but they'll also benefit from other types of calming strategies alongside it.
medium.strength:
Include some movement options:
• **Shake it out** — 30 seconds of full-body shaking, then freeze
• **Wall push-ups** — push against the wall 10 times
• **Stretching** — simple yoga poses (downward dog, child's pose)
• Pair these with a quieter strategy for best results

low.headline: Movement isn't their go-to
low.detail: Your child doesn't naturally seek physical release when upset. Forcing them to "run it off" might actually increase their stress. They regulate through other channels — look at their sensory and verbal scores for better-matched strategies.
low.concern: Skip high-energy calming tools for now. Gentle movement (rocking, swaying, slow walking) may work better than intense activity.

high.headline: Sensory input is their anchor
high.detail: Your child is highly tuned into sensory experience — they seek out specific textures, pressures, and inputs when overwhelmed. A well-stocked sensory toolkit will be your most powerful calming resource.
high.strength:
Build these into the toolkit:
• **Calm-down bin** — playdough, kinetic sand, water beads, fidget toys in a box they can grab
• **Heavy work** — weighted lap pad, stuffed animal with weight, or a heavy blanket
• **Deep pressure** — firm hugs, "burrito roll" in a blanket, compression vest
• **Oral input** — chewy snacks, frozen fruit, a water bottle with a straw
• **Noise reduction** — kid-safe ear defenders or noise-canceling headphones for overstimulating environments

medium.headline: Some sensory tools will help
medium.detail: Your child responds to sensory input but doesn't rely on it exclusively. Having a few tactile tools available is smart, even if they're not the primary strategy.
medium.strength:
Keep these on hand:
• **Fidget tools** — a few different textures to cycle through
• **Cozy corner** — a soft space with a blanket where they can retreat
• **Water play** — simple hand-washing or splashing can be surprisingly regulating
• Let them choose which sensory tools feel right

low.headline: Sensory tools aren't a match — yet
low.detail: Your child doesn't naturally gravitate toward tactile or sensory soothing. That doesn't mean sensory tools won't ever work, but they're not the first thing to reach for when things get big.
low.concern: Don't force sensory tools if they're not interested. Some kids find fidgets distracting rather than calming. Focus on strategies that match their other scores.

high.headline: Talking it through works
high.detail: Your child can use words and cognitive strategies to process emotions. They benefit from naming feelings, understanding causes, and being walked through what's happening in their body and brain.
high.strength:
Build these into the toolkit:
• **Feelings check-in** — "What's the feeling? Where do you feel it in your body? What do you need?"
• **Feelings chart** — visual chart on the wall they can point to
• **Breathing exercises** — "smell the flowers, blow out the candles" or box breathing
• **Problem-solving script** — "What happened? How do I feel? What can I do?"
• **Countdown** — "Let's count backward from 10 together"
• **Debrief ritual** — after the storm passes, review what happened and what helped

medium.headline: Words help — but timing matters
medium.detail: Your child can use verbal and cognitive strategies, but usually not in the peak of the storm. These tools work best as a follow-up — after the initial wave passes and they're ready to think again.
medium.strength:
Use these AFTER the peak:
• **Simple choices** — "Do you want a hug or some space?"
• **Visual prompts** — a simple feelings poster or 3-step calming card
• **Breathing together** — model it rather than instructing
• Save the conversation for when they're calm — don't try to reason with a flooded brain

low.headline: Words aren't the way in — yet
low.detail: Right now, verbal strategies aren't effective during or after emotional episodes. Your child either can't access language when overwhelmed, or doesn't yet have the developmental readiness for cognitive calming techniques. That's OK — there are better entry points.
low.concern: Skip the explanations during meltdowns. Focus on physical presence, sensory tools, or movement first. You can gently introduce emotion words later — but the body needs to calm before the brain can learn.

movement-primary.headline: Your Child's Toolkit: Body-First Calming
movement-primary.subheadline: They need to move it to lose it.
movement-primary.explanation: Your child processes emotions through their body first. The most effective calming strategies will involve physical release, sensory input, and hands-on tools. Cognitive strategies can come second — once the body is calm, the brain can engage.
nextSteps: Set up a designated calm-down space with physical tools (trampoline, squeeze toys, crash pad)
Build a "when I'm upset" routine that starts with movement before talking
Practice calming strategies when they're already calm — so they're familiar when the storm hits
movement-primary.watchOutFor: Physical regulation needs can look like "bad behavior" to others. Advocate for your child's need to move — it's not acting out, it's self-regulation.
movement-primary.encouragement: A child who knows how to use their body to regulate is learning a lifelong skill. Most adults still haven't figured this out. You're building it in early.
movement-primary.comparativeContext: Occupational therapy research shows that physical regulation strategies are the most effective starting point for young children.

balanced-toolkit.headline: Your Child's Toolkit: The Mix & Match Kit
balanced-toolkit.subheadline: They benefit from variety — different tools for different moments.
balanced-toolkit.explanation: Your child doesn't have one dominant regulation channel — they use a mix of physical, sensory, and verbal strategies depending on the situation. This is actually an advantage: it means you can build a versatile toolkit and let them choose what fits the moment.
nextSteps: Offer 2-3 strategy choices during calm-down: "Do you want to squeeze something, take breaths, or go for a run?"
Rotate strategies so they build a wide repertoire
Notice which strategies work for which triggers — anger might need movement while sadness might need sensory
balanced-toolkit.watchOutFor: Having too many options during a meltdown can be overwhelming. Narrow it to 2 choices in the heat of the moment.
balanced-toolkit.encouragement: A flexible regulation toolkit means your child is building multiple pathways to calm. That's the goal for all kids — and yours is getting there naturally.
balanced-toolkit.comparativeContext: The Zones of Regulation framework recommends building a diverse toolkit rather than relying on a single strategy.

gentle-approach.headline: Your Child's Toolkit: Start Gentle, Build Slowly
gentle-approach.subheadline: Less is more right now — simplicity and presence are the tools.
gentle-approach.explanation: Your child is still early in developing self-regulation skills, and that's completely normal. Right now, the most effective "tool" is you — your calm presence, your co-regulation, your predictability. The toolkit will grow as they do.
nextSteps: Focus on YOUR calm first — you are the primary regulation tool right now
Start with just one simple strategy and practice it daily when things are calm
Create a predictable calm-down routine: same place, same sequence, every time
gentle-approach.watchOutFor: Don't introduce too many strategies at once. One well-practiced tool beats ten that haven't been rehearsed.
gentle-approach.encouragement: Co-regulation — where your calm helps their calm — IS the toolkit right now. Every time you stay regulated while they fall apart, you're literally building their brain's capacity to do it for themselves later.
gentle-approach.comparativeContext: Stuart Shanker's research shows that self-regulation is always preceded by co-regulation. Your child learning to borrow your calm is the necessary first step.
